bibl.title: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Philip Showalter Hench, November 15, 1947

div1.p: Redd sends Hench a transcription of a 1901 letter from Reed to Carter in which Reed states that Carter's work in Mississippi greatly impressed upon him the importance of an intermediate host for yellow fever. Redd refers Hench to an article on Carter, by Griffitts, in "The Southern Medical Journal."

div1.head: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Philip Showalter Hench, November 15, 1947
div1.p:
Commissioner of Accounts and Commissioner in
Chancery of Circuit Court of Hanover County
H. CARTER REDD
ATTORNEY-AT-LAW
1104 TRAVELERS BUILDING
RICHMOND, VA.
Nov. 15th. 1947 Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Charlottsville, Va.,
My dear Sir:-

You may have Copy of the letter below. If not it may
be of some interest to you.

WAR DEPARTMENT
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE.
Army Medical Museum and Library,
WASHINGTON.

Please accept my sincere thanks for the senti-
ments expressed in your kind letter of Feb. 21st - I value highly
your opinion of our work- Since I know of no one more competent
to pass judgment on all that pertains to the subject of yellow
fever- You must not forget that your own work in Missippi did
more to impress me with the importance of an intermediate host
than every thing else put together.

Copy of letter written to Dr. Henry Rose Carter Sr.
Dr. T. H. D. Griffitts

Savannah, Georgia, has some references in his article
HENRY ROSE CARTER, THE SCIENTIST AND THE MAN appearing in the
Southern Medical Journal Aug. 1930, Vol. 32 No. 8, pp 841-848
